column1: El Mahalla El Kubra consists of two words: El Mahalla in Arabic means "district" or "encampment"
column2: El Kubra means "great". Hence the title collectively means "The Great Encampment". It's a rough translation of a Coptic Egyptian name ϯϣⲁⲓⲣⲓ "cohabitation" or "residence"
column3: but the second part of it – "El Kubra" may come from the Hellenistic name of the same settlement – "Theodosiou Nixis" (Coptic: ⲑⲉⲟⲇⲱⲥⲓⲟⲩ ⲛⲓⲝⲓⲥ
column4: where ⲛⲓⲝⲓⲥ is most likely a Greek transcription of Coptic ⲛⲓϣϯ – "great").

column1: El Mahalla El Kubra was known as "Theodosiou" (Coptic: ⲑⲉⲟⲇⲱⲥⲓⲟⲩ) or "Theodosiou Nixis" (Coptic: ⲑⲉⲟⲇⲱⲥⲓⲟⲩ ⲛⲓⲝⲓⲥ
column2: where ⲛⲓⲝⲓⲥ is most likely a Greek transcription of Coptic ⲛⲓϣϯ – "great") (which might refer to Hibiscus cannabinus) in Ptolematic and Roman Egypt
